name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: [SOUND] This lecture is about

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the probabilistic retrieval model.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In this lecture
column6: we're going to continue the discussion of text retrieval methods. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: We're going to look at another kind of very different way to design ranking

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _functions
column6: then the Vector Space Model that we discussed before. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: In probabilistic models we define the ranking function based

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: on the probability that this document is random to this query.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In other words
column6: we are
column7: we introduced a binary random variable here. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: This is the variable R here.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And we also assume that the query and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the documents are all observations from random variables.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Note that in the vector space model
column6: we assume they are vectors. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: But here we assumed we assumed they are the data observed from random variables.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And so the problem
column6: model retrieval _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: becomes to estimate the probability of relevance.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In this category of models
column6: there are different variants. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _The classic probabilistic model has led to the BM25 retrieval function

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _which we discussed in the vector space model

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: because it's form is actually similar to a vector space model.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In this lecture
column6: we're going to discuss another subclass in _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: this big class called a language modeling approaches to retrieval.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In particular
column6: we're going to discuss the Query Likelihood retrieval model

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: which is one of the most effective models in probabilistic models.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _There is also another line called a divergence-from-randomness model

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: which has latitude the PL2 function.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: It's also one of the most effective state of the art attribute functions.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In query likelihood
column6: our assumption is that this probability readiness _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: can be approximated by the probability of query given a document and readiness.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So
column6: intuitively
column7: this probability just captures the following probability. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And that is if a user likes document d
column6: how likely would _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the user enter query q in order to retrieve document d.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So we'll assume that the user likes d
column6: because we have a relevance value here. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And the we ask the question about how likely we will see this

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: particular query from this user?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So this is the basic idea.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Now to understand this idea
column6: let's take a look at the general idea or _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the basic idea of probabilistic retrieval models.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So here
column6: I listed some imagined relevance status values or _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: relevance judgments of queries and documents.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _For example
column6: in this slide

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: is a query that the user typed in and d1 is a document the user has seen and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: one means the user thinks d1 is relevant to to q1.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So this R here can be also approximated by the clicks little data that the search

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: engine can collect it by watching how you interact with the search results.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So
column6: in this case
column8: the user clicked on this document

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: there's a one here.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Similarly
column6: the user clicked on d2 also

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In other words
column6: d2 is assumed to relevant at two

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _On the other hand
column6: d3 is non relevant

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And d4 is non-relevant and then d 5 is again relevant and so on and so forth.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And this part of maybe
column6: they are collected from a different user. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Right. So this user typed in q1 and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _then found that d1 is actually not useful
column6: so d1 is actually non-relevant. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In contrast here we see it's relevant and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _or this could be the same query typing by the same user at different times

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _but d2 is also relevant
column6: et cetera. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And then here
column6: we can see more data that about other queries. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Now we can imagine
column6: we have a lot of search data. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Now we can ask the question

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: how can we then estimated the probability of relevance?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Right. So

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: how can we compute this probability of relevance?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Well
column6: intuitively
column7: that just means if we look at the

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _all the entries where we see this particular d and this particular q

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: how likely will we see a one on the third column?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Basically
column6: that just means we can correct the counts. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: We can first count how many times where we see q and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: d as a pair in this table and then count how many times

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: we actually have also seen one in the third column and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: then we just compute the ratio.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So let's take a look at some specific examples.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Suppose we are trying to computed this probability for d1
column6: d2 and d3 for q1. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: What is the estimated probability?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Now think about that.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: You can pause the video if needed.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Try to take a look at the table and

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: try to give your estimate of the probability.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Have you seen that if we are interested in q1 and d1
column6: we've been looking at the

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _these two pairs and in both cases or actually in one of the cases

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _the user has said that this is one
column6: this is relevant. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So R is equal to 1 in only one of the two cases.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In the other case
column6: this is zero. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So that's one out of two.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: What about the d1 and the d2?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Well
column6: they're are here

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In both cases
column6: in this case R is equal to 1. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So
column6: it's two out of two and so and so forth. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So you can see with this approach

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: we captured it score these documents for the query.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Right?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _We now have a score for d1
column6: d2 and d3 for this query. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: We can simply ranked them based on these probabilities and so

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: that's the basic idea of probabilistic retrieval model.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And you can see
column6: it makes a lot of sense. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In this case
column6: it's going to rank d2 above all the other documents. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Because in all the cases
column6: when you have seen q1 and d2

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: The user clicked on this document.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So this also showed showed that with a lot of click through data

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: a search engine can learn a lot from the data to improve the search engine.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _This is a simple example that shows that with even a small number of entries here

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: we can already estimate some probabilities.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: These probabilities would give us some sense about which document might be more

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: read or more useful to a user for typing this query.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Now
column6: of course
column7: the problem is that we don't observe all the queries and _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: all of the documents and all the relevance values.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Right?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: There will be a lot of unseen documents.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In general
column6: we can only collect data from the document's that we have shown to _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the users.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _There are even more unseen queries

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: because you cannot predict what queries will be typed in by users.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So
column6: obviously

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: if we apply it to unseen queries or unseen documents.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Nevertheless
column6: this shows the basic idea of the probabilistic retrieval model and _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: it makes sense intuitively.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So what do we do in such a case when we have a lot of unseen documents and
column6: and _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: unseen queries?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Well
column6: the solutions that we have to approximate in some way. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Right. So
column6: in this particular case called _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _the Query LIkelihood Retrieval Model
column6: we just approximate this _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _by another conditional probability
column6: p q | d

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So
column6: in the condition part
column7: we assume that the user likes the document

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: because we have seen that the user clicked on this document.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And this part

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: shows that we're interested in how likely the user would actually enter this query.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: How likely we will see this query in the same row.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So note that here
column6: we have made an interesting assumption here. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Basically
column6: we
column7: we're going to assume that whether the user types in this _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: query has something to do with whether user likes the document.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _In other words
column6: we actually make the foreign assumption and _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: that is a user formula to query based on an imaginary relevant document.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Well
column6: if you just look at this as a conditional probability

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: it's not obvious we are making this assumption.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So what I really meant is that to use this new

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: conditional probability to help us score

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: then this new condition of probability.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: We have to somehow be able to estimate this conditional

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: probability without relying on this big table.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Otherwise
column6: it would be having similar problems as before. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And by making this assumption
column6: we have some way to bypass this big table and _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: try to just mortar how to use a formula to the query.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Okay. So this is how you can simplify the

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the general model so that we can give either specific function later.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: So let's look at how this model works for our example.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And basically

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: what we are going to do in this case is to ask the following question.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: Which of these documents is most likely the imaginary relevant document in

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the user's mind when the user formulates this query?

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And so we ask this question and we quantify the probability and this

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: probability is a conditional probability of observing this query if a particular

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: document is in fact the imaginary relevant document in the user's mind.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Here you can see we compute all these query likelihood probabilities

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: the likelihood of queries given each document.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Once we have these values

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: we can then rank these documents based on these values.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _So to summarize
column6: the general idea of modern relevance in the probability _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _risk model is to assume that we introduce a binary random variable
column6: R here. _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And then let the scoring function be defined based on this conditional

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: probability.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: We also talked about a proximate in this [SOUND] by using the query likelihood.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _And in this case
column6: we have a ranking function that's _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: basically based on a probability of a query given the document.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And this probability should be interpreted as the probability

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: that a user who likes document d would pose query q.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _Now the question
column6: of course is how do we compute this additional probability? _

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: _At this in general has to do with how to compute the probability of text

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: because q is a text.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
text: And this has to do with a model called a Language Model.

name: 4 - 1 - 3.1 Probabilistic Retrieval Model- Basic Idea (00-12-44).srt
